Comments_List: Financial modeling
I became more familiar with excel, which was one of the most important takeaways for me.
financial modeling and renewable energy related
Financial modeling, knowledge of energy technology and markets, ability to summarize legal documents
I learned how to build financial models, how to read legal documents

- Renewable project financing (excel modelling)
- Reviewing, summarizing and understanding legal agreements related to project financing
- The engineering concepts behind renewable energy power plants e.g. wind and solar

excel, project planning, legal documents reading

project finance
energy market
excel

Overall knowledge of project finance structure, process, and risks; basic knowledge of renewable energy technologies' evolution and current status; skills acquired included reading and summarizing legal documents, financial models, excel formatting, financial analysis.

I learnt about energy markets, renewable energy from a market standpoint, making sense of legal documents that had previously been intimidating, financial modeling skills that are at par with professional standards, some physics(!), and lots of excel formulae and lingo. This was  one of my favorite classes at Yale.
Project Analysis, Financial Modelling, insights of renewable industry
Best class taken at Yale. Should be compulsory for every manager to take this class, but maybe is the influence of the great Dan Gross
Project finance, accounting, taxes, renewable energy, application of project finance to new areas, financial modeling
project finance, financial modeling, taxes, accounting, managing funds, how renewable energy works, application to other areas.
Learned so much about energy finance, financial modeling skills.
Lots of Excel modeling, lots of insight into the world of renewable energies and how they come about. Tons of practical material in this course - excellent for real world skill building.

I learned so so much. I started off with no excel knowledge, very little project finance knowledge, and a ton of heart. And love for Renewable Energy. I left it with a better understanding of excel (though never perfect), some great conversations, and a really good learning experience. Dan definitely delivered and taught well -- which is not easy for a 3 hour course to keep people engaged.

I think he did such a fantastic job -- cannot speak highly enough.

Understanding how renewable energy projects are financed, how that structure can be used to finance other types of projects, problems with the current way of financing RE, nuances of modeling a RE project, familiarity with legal requirements of project finance, and so much more!
Project finance, financial modeling
Financial modeling (tons of Excel) and legal documentation of renewable energy projects.

Skills in advanced financial modeling and creating term sheets for legal documents.
Deep knowledge in renewable energy and project finance.
Advanced excel, financial concepts, perseverence.
This is the BEST course that I have taken at Yale. I wish that all of the courses I take would equip me with skills as practically useful and the ones that I gained from REPF.

How to build a financial model for a renewable energy project, and all the relevant components/concepts. E.g. how to model/size debt, interpret legal contracts, forecast wind/solar output, model taxes and tax benefits/liabilities, organize a balance sheet/income statement, etc. I also gained an intro to different types of renewable energy technologies, and the types of markets in which renewable energy project finance is particularly viable.
Understanding of project finance, financial modeling skills.
This was a wonderful course that taught strong excel financial modeling skills.
This is by far the best course I have taken to date at Yale. Thanks to this course, I will be working with a solar developer over the summer on financial modeling and contract analysis.
Financial modeling, renewable energy technologies
Learned how to build financial models in excel.
Financial concepts in clear energy, excel skills to build up a financial model, skills to summary legal contracts.

Renewable Energy Project Finance was excellent. 

Knowledge: The overarching goal of REPF was to give its students a sense of how a project finance company is created and operated. We gained lots of industry-specific knowledge, including but not limited to: the international dynamics that shape the domestic wind/solar project finance industry, the science behind solar panels and wind turbines, the history of the renewable energy industry in the US, and the tax laws that govern project finance. A lot of the teaching material is proprietary, which isn't just cool but highlights how unique an opportunity this class is.

Skills: Each week of homework alternated in its focus: one week on financial modeling and one week on legal analysis. To put it simply, we learned how to build project finance models in Excel and how to read challenging legal documents outlining the terms and conditions of a real-world wind project. These skills are not specific to renewable energy, and I'm certain they will follow me to my future work. 

Insights: I would say the biggest gains from this course came from getting to observe the care, professionalism, and expertise that Professor Gross brought to the class. He's quite the role model, and I think most people will love having him as a teacher.
Modeling in excel and financial and policy considerations of renewable energy projects.
Grand introduction to renewable energy, Financial Modeling, Reviewing various agreements in renewable energy projects.
I learned so much about excel and how to model wind farms and solar farms!
Financial modeling of renewable energy projects and debt loans.
How project development works, how to build a financial model, the specifics of the renewable energy development space, reading contracts, current events in the space.
Real-world knowledge of financial modelling.
Project finance, Excel, navigating loan agreements, debt and equity, tax

I learned a great deal about the world of renewable energy project finance and how to apply class concepts to real-world settings. My incoming knowledge of financial concepts was pretty sparse, so I gained a good amount of background understanding around finance terms like loans, equity investments, etc. as well as a much better handle on the use of excel for financial modeling. Through the homeworks and final model, I also gained clarity on how project finance works on the ground.
Project financing skills and Insights into the renewable energy sector
Financial modeling, renewable energy

Financial modelling on excel
Some knowledge of how renewable energy and projects work

I went from knowing absolutely nothing about finance to gaining a background on the process and usefulness of project finance, as well as a reasonable level of comfort with modeling techniques and legal contracts.
Advanced financial modeling, basics of project finance, legal documentation, energy science, energy markets, financial innovation

Before taking this course, I barely knew anything about building a financial model. Now I have a working financial model that I built from scratch. Those skills alone make taking the course worthwhile, let alone the fantastic instruction from Dan Gross.
I learned the basics of financial modeling, got an overview of how electricity systems and power plants work, and learned about the legal framework that power plant developers work within.

This was the first time someone methodically taught me to use Excel. It tied together concepts from the SOM core curriculum and other classes in ways that I really appreciated. I had heard  great things and it absolutely met my high expectations.

The class is heavy on financial analysis and modeling, and it would have been even better if I had a basic understanding of these foundation concepts. However, that is not on the class or professor to teach, and I only wish I had come in with a little bit more background knowledge. The course is structured in a logical manner, and the professor clearly put in a lot of thought into each and every lecture.
better than my expectation
It aligned with my expectations very well.
Excellent!! Dan leaves up to my expectation!

- In short, very well. I went into the class not knowing much about project finance, let alone how to code a dynamic financial model, and left the seminar with a valuable skill set related to renewable energy project finance. I also gained a deeper appreciation of the complexities of renewable energy project development. These skills are extremely useful for me going forward, since I hope to find a job in the field.

Very well.

WELL EXCEEDED. I had heard this class was great, but its hands down the best class Ive taken at Yale.
Not only did they align, but they far exceeded my expectations.

This class is the best course I have taken at FES. I have gained a lot through this class. The knowledge and skills acquired are in complete alignment with most of my expectations. 

One aspect that I expected from this course was: detailed discussion on securitization of renewable energy loans. This topic was briefly discussed for 1/2hr in class-2. I think this is very important for emerging markets and needs atleast one complete session + one homework.
I learned more than I thought I would, for sure
It aligned with my expectations, but was more focused on excel modeling than I expected. It was often about how to carry out the problem sets in excel instead of a renewable energy class.
Exceeded!
Very well
Very well
Well  I'd heard great things about this class and it was indeed a well-taught, well-structured course.
Absolutely aligned.
Well aligned with expectations. Learned even more than expected.
Well I guess
Perfectly
They exceeded my expectations! I don't think I've ever learned so much in such a clear structured way.
The skills I gained far exceeded my expectations.
This class far exceeded my expectations. I had heard the class would help me model energy projects, but I learned so much more.

I appreciated building on previous homeworks. Even more of that would be appreciated, particularly around the balance sheets. I also would have liked more best practices for laying out models, since I wouldn't really know where to start on a model I have to build from scratch. We started with a template for operations, which was great, but never discussed the ways in which the balance sheet template was different. Perhaps this could be a TA session. 

I would prefer the optional HW #10 be due after the basic model. I wanted to do a model that was more advanced than the basic model but less advanced than the enhanced model, and maybe HW #10 could be structured a little differently (and timed differently) to be complementary to the basic model. Students could do three levels of cumulative skill-building final projects: the basic model, or basic + HW 10, or enhanced.
strengths: very practical
This is an incredibly strong course.

Strength:
Super organized lectures with logical flow, clear instruction on the assignment
some homework are challenging but intellectually stimulating 
homework feedbacks are clear and easy to understand

Strengths: 
- Rigorous assignments and quick feedback once submitted; feedback was also personalised
- TAs were helpful, experienced and always available
- Professor Gross was engaging and knowledgeable 
- Recitation sessions for specific concepts were very useful

Weaknesses:
- It would be nice to have video captures of the lectures provided on canvas for revision of concepts at later periods 
- More recitation sessions for the final project would be helpful, especially for concepts not covered in class
it would be great to provide more guidance in the beginning on how to model in excel and share the class videos

The course was extremely well taught. It was highly organized and intentional in the sequencing of concepts and progression of ideas. The course balanced 'theory' with practical skills and contextualized materials in a compelling way. I really enjoyed the final portion of the course dedicated to 'beyond project finance' and would appreciate more time or supplemental materials devoted to applying project finance models in other arenas.

This course caters to students from rather varied educational backgrounds. As an Econ student, I did not have much knowledge of accounting standards and corporate-sounding documents, or even energy markets for that matter. However, I know that lots of other students had either one of both of those skill sets. The way Prof Dan structured this class meant that people like me were able to not only keep up with, but also compete with the students who had pre-existing knowledge of these concepts.
I found the pace of the class perfect for me, but I respect that some may have found it slow because they knew certain things beforehand.

I wish we could have more classes with Prof Dan. I believe that if he could teach this class twice a week or teach another course as well students would benefit so much, because he is a really good teacher.
Like the group projects and wish to have more of those assignments so we get better ideas of how projects actually go in the real world.
The biggest strength of the class is the professor Daniel Gross. The weakness is that if this class was taught by probably any other professor it would not have a quarter of its success

Strengths:
This is one of, if not the best, class I've taken in the last three years of my SOM/FES joint degree. Daniel is exceptional as a subject matter expert and teacher alike. I feel that I have an incredibly concrete skill that is specific to renewable energy but can also be applied to other areas.
This is the best class I've taken in three year at Yale. The applied learning brings abstract concepts to life, and Daniel is exceptional.
One of the best lecturers at FES, one of the best and most useful classes at FES.
Dan was an excellent lecturer and the course was structured really well. I'm not sure I would change anything.

No major weaknesses with the course -- the TAs were incredible, Dan was great. I spoke to Dan about how some topics in energy feel a little redundant in terms of the overall curriculum (i.e. you talk about certain things in a few classes and it is better to have them build) but most of things feel reinforcing here, especially with Financing Green Tech.

No weaknesses -- just a lot of work -- so no complaints. Maybe on the final model a little more help on some of the newer topics (i.e. back leverage) but other than that -- all good.

My only suggestions for improvement is to provide the slides on periodicity earlier in the semester (not necessarily including it in lecture or recitation that early, but just having the explanatory slides). I remember wanting to get started on the final enhanced model during spring break, but having absolutely no idea how to even set up the time periods.

The course could be improved by providing templates for the models. It is likely that in the working world a firm will have a template to work from. If not, it would be helpful to have a professional template from this class to use. It would eliminate a certain amount of time on formatting that does not benefit the learning from a content perspective.
Great teaching, extremely practical skills. Sometimes the amount of work can be overwhelming.

Dan Gross is phenomenal, he is the strength of this class. The slides are so well made and all the topics build on each other incredibly well. I am so impressed with the course structure and assignments.
There could be more support in form of additional office hours by TAs.
Maybe less loan agreement stuff and more weekly class time - maybe two two hour sessions?

Only suggestion would be for online mid-semester feedback through something like Feedback Box (www.thefeedbackbox.com). It seems like a lot of labor, energy and human resources to administer paper surveys.  Feedback box can be used throughout the semester as well. So students could submit anonymous feedback to their professors any time throughout the course.
NONE

Dan Gross is a very engaging lecturer - he has a talent for making complex/dense content interesting and digestible. The homework assignments were quite challenging, but really important to understand and master. I valued using real-world documents and projects for our assignments. 

As for weaknesses, I felt that the group Investor Memo could have been a more effective project. A different group project I might recommend would be to have students think about "outside the box" options where project finance could be applied to other sustainability challenges (such as the African streetlight example and Elle and Vince's proposal, which we covered in our make-up session). Even though I am energy-focused, this type of project would have given non-energy students an opportunity to begin flesh out the ways in which project finance could apply back to their areas of focus/interest. 

The final model project seemed to have a few glitches, which I think could be ironed out. Several updates to the final model assignment were made in the final weeks, as students were already working on the model, and coming across issues/errors. I think this is probably inevitable for such a complex project, but some elements could definitely be tightened up for next year.

Great lecture, especially on difficult financial topics. Very well thought through. Really good homework assignments and feedback. I think the one class with a half-session dedicated to modeling skills could have been taught in recitation.

Very strong in the amount of content the course covered - it was fast paced and well-taught. The TAs did a great job with grading the homework and they were were crucial to the success of the class as their detailed feedback really helped me learn from my mistakes.
I wish Dan could teach more classes! This year Dan introduced a group project option into the assignments and I do not think it was successful, I'd recommend rethinking that piece for next year.
It was a great course! Exceeded my expectations

Dan Gross is certainly the greatest strength of the course. Not only is he an excellent lecturer and curriculum-builder, but he sets a balanced tone of professionalism and warmth that encourages every student to perform at their best without intimidation or rudeness.
Really interesting subject material. Some assignments are a slog but useful.

Many strengths, no weakness.

Excellent instructor, Very well structured curriculum, Well designed homeworks, Responsive TAs.

Excel tips/ formulae would have consumed atleast 5 hours of class time. I think the instructor can raise the bar higher here, and provide detailed tutorials in excel wherever applicable.
Strength is Daniel Gross and all the excel work. Weakness is how long the lecture is because its difficult to pay attention. I loved the this week in news segment!

Well taught and organized. Clear assignments with concrete objectives. I especially liked the "in the news" class openers. I know the class is about finance, but I wish it was less about excel and more about how to analyze the value of a prospective renewable energy project. Those two objectives may be similar, but if excel were to fall out of favor in the next 10-20 years, I might have trouble connecting the class ideas to other software given that the class focused so heavily on excel.

Strengths - Dan Gross is a freakin' all-star. Lectures are impeccably constructed and delivered, homeworks are challenging but achievable, TA recitations and office hours are very helpful.

Weaknesses - a 3-hr lecture on a Monday is killer.

Strengths: lectures, TA review sessions, content
Weaknesses: clarity in homework assignments, answer keys are formatted differently which can get confusing
More hardcore science
Great structure, level of challenge, and insights gained all around, no improvements to suggest.
Course was taught at a good pace with a good build up. However, there is not enough feedback or help from TAs.

Strengths
- Very good foundation in financial modeling. Funny to see an exodus of MBAs leaving SOM every Monday, going to another school to learn how to do financial modeling. 
- Though im not planning on working in renewable energy, really appreciated the combination of project finance + renewable energy. Good to apply the skill set to a worthwhile industry.
- Very much appreciated the pragmatism of the class. Real world topics. 
- 3 hour class duration is rough. Can it be 2 hours?



Weaknesses
 - I chose to do the advanced model and am happy I did. It was a good level of challenge, but the amount of time and exercises required for the financial model were much too much. When there are dozens of students crowding around the TAs during every office hours, something is off. It seems TAs should be a back-up support if needed, not heavily leaned on by dozens of students.  It took an extraordinary amount of time. I think the level of challenge was good, but there should be fewer components so that it can be completed in a more reasonable time frame. 
- Some of the material covered in the later classes was less interesting. 
- Didnt find the guest lecture to be helpful.

Strengths: clear curriculum, gets you financial modelling skills, classes well structured and thoughtful
Weakness: professor is self indulgent, professor complains about taking feedback or boasts about it, professor lays out grades for each assignment as if that would be helpful for everyone in the room, professor made some inappropriate comments about mental health or gender, assignments expect level of knowledge not gone over in class or prerequired, recitation sessions basically make the class five hours a week instead of three, feedback from the TAs also expected a certain level of knowledge just to understand the feedback

Strengths: Very clear teaching, assignments that build on one another, sensible structure, great mix of disciplines, very practically focused, accessible to a variety of backgrounds and skill levels

Weaknesses: Three-hour lectures tended to drag (switching between various topics was helpful), guest lecturers were a disappointment (hard to compare to Dan in terms of clarity and teaching ability)

Strengths of the class include the thorough instruction from Dan Gross and the skills gained by building a dynamic financial model on Excel. The assignment I wasn't a huge fan of was the group investment memo. This seemed like a strange assignment to work on over spring break, and I felt like it took time away from building my final model without adding too much value to the class. Otherwise this class was fantastic!
Daniel Gross is an incredible lecturer. He makes dry material engaging and puts together a great group of TAs to help you understand material outside of the classroom.
Take this, even if you're not an energy person!
Work hard and you shall be rewarded. If you put the time and effort necessary into this class, you will gain incredibly valuable skills.
Take this class!!!
Be prepared to spend a good amount of time per week going through concepts and modelling. The process is difficult but it'll be worth it!
should have some basic knowledge of financing

Take this class! Initially, it might seem overwhelming or challenging with you do not have a finance or quant background however, the support is provided both inside and outside of class and you are set up to succeed and grow, as long as you focus and put in the time.

Attend each and every lecture even if you think you have a sense of what might be taught because the way Prof Dan teaches is extremely clear and concise.
Take advantage of the TA resources made available through office hours and recitations sessions, they are all going to be very helpful people who ar genuinely interested in your progress as an individual student.

Take this class and it is great. 
It helps you learn a lot about energy industry
It should be compulsory. Whoever misses it would miss an important part of the potential experience at Yale.
Stay on top of the work, don't let any early assignments slip.
It's a must-take class.
Take the class, go to office hours with Dan. Take advantage of the TAs.
Take it if you are interested in learning to build a financial model or interested in renewable energy!
Take it! Lots of hard work but so worth it. You'll learn so much!

Take it. Prepare to work. But you'll get so much out of it if you do -- and don't worry about the grades.

As good as it gets in terms of course I've taken, but be prepared for a lot of work.
Absolutely take it if you're even remotely interested in renewable energy!

Great course if you want to learn more about finance or if you are interested in the practical aspects of green energy. You will also learn about the legal framework surrounding these projects which is also practical. It is a lot of work so do not take it if you are not prepared to put extra time in.
It would be foolish not to take this class if remotely interested in energy and/or project finance.
This is one of the best classes I've taken at Yale - Professor Gross is truly the best.  I'm grateful that he has made the decision to teach part-time.
Make time to go to office hours.
Take it if you are ready to commit and put in the work and the time, which are a lot. If you do, it will be the best course you have ever taken. If not, you will suffer.
I would definitely recommend the course, but warn that it is a considerable work load and requires a large time commitment if you are going to get as much out of the class as possible.
Take this class! Try the advanced model.
Be prepared to put in some time to this class, but it is well worth it!
You are crazy if you don't take this class while you are at F&ES
It's quite a bit of work but you'll learn a lot!
TAKE IT.

Take it. Make sure you make an effort to be well-rested for the 3-hour Monday lectures, because they can wear on. Make use of having access to Professor Gross (which is an amazing privilege) and the well-trained TAs if you ever have questions. Again, take it.
Be ready to work! Lots of excel but lots of really interesting knowledge gained from lecture.
I think this class should be made as mandatory FES course for all MEM students.
Use office hours and recitation sessions! Get going on assignments early.
It's a great and demanding, but fair class. Start the problem sets early in the week to ask TAs for help. Sunday night crams are very difficult on these assignments.
Take it!
Take this course.
Take it even if you aren't interested in renewable energy

Be prepared to invest a lot of time into the work associated with this class  it's really the only way you'll get a lot out of it. Take advantage of the TA office hours and their willingness to be a resource; I found the TAs invaluable to helping me master some of the work and applications of the class, given my lack of familiarity with excel and financial modeling going into it.
This is an extremely time intensive course. Be mentally prepared.
Take it. And set aside time for it.
Don't do it unless you are focused on energy and/or feel like you absolutely need financial modelling skills that you cannot get in any other course

As someone who took this class knowing it had nothing to do with my field of study, I enjoyed the experience although I'm not sure if I'll ever use this again. If you are hoping to work in something related to sustainable finance, I imagine this class is a must-take.

This is a superb course! Come with at least an interest in project finance and renewable energy. It's a fantastic financial modeling class, but the other components are a big part of the course as well. Also, be willing to devote time and energy to the assignments, beause you get out what you put in REPF is one of the best classes Yale has to offer. Other courses should follow this model (taught by a practitioner, heavy focus on real-world skills, well-structured, lessons build on one another to reach a productive endpoint).
Give it a shot! It's a lot of work, but you will receive all the support you need as long as you ask for it.
This is a challenging class, but if you work hard, you can get so much out of it. One of- if not the best class I've taken at Yale.
